description:
In August 1942, the US Marine Corps suddenly landed on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomon Islands. The success or failure of supply by sea transportation was crucial.

For the first time in history, this game recreates Guadalcanal's land and water battles on the same map!
Both games can be played individually or can also be linked. In the land-sea game combined play, the naval battle determines the amount of supplies arriving on Guadalcanal and also the success or failure of land artillery. Artillery greatly influences the land battlefield.

Number of counters: 

    land: about 50 units + 50 markers
    sea: 120


Map: 1 full size
Game period:  

    land:  September-November 1942 (7 turns) 
    sea: 1 turn 5 minutes (6 to 16 turns


Unit size:    1 unit = 1 battalion or 1 ship 
Map area:    North coast of Guadalcanal Island and near the north 
Play time:    About 1 to 2 hours 
Number of players:    2 people
Play time:     1-3 hours (depending on the scenario)

adapted from publisher's website

15 year old Dylan Cuboid was about to decorate the Christmas tree.
It was his turn this year and he had decided to make it something extra special for this year! His two older siblings, „the Twins" Brenda and Brandon, have had their "coming out" this year. Duh... Literally everybody knew about it, but these two needed there special piece of pie of course... :D So Dylan decided to decorate the Christmas tree in rainbow colors from top to bottom to celebrate with them once more in pride!
But there was an obstacle.
You know, the Cuboid family, they have a tradition. Whoever took down the decorations last year has to decorate the tree this year. That's how he had gotten his assignment. But back then he had not been the forward thinking and well organized Dylan of today. He was a kid, who wanted to get things over with to play with the toys he had been gifted. And so the boxes were not cleanly sorted like he would have liked them to be now...
So he needs a little help!

The gameplay consists of dice manipulation by using the powers of said dice. The tree decorating part is RnR

The Cuboids' Proud Christmas was an entry to the 10th Anniversary Christmas PnP contest. It's WIP-Thread can be found here:
[WIP] The Cuboids' Proud Christmas - 10th anniversary Christmas Print and Play Game contest!

Two players try to move their four pieces over a board to the opposite corner. The pieces may not lose contact with each other; there are various difficulty levels, in some of them they need to stay in touch in numerical order as well (they are numbered 1-4). 
A die determines the number of pieces that can be played on the turn of a player.

An educational game collection for 2-4 kids to learn colours, forms and numbers. It consists of a jump and run game, a treasure hunt and a fast reaction game. Some of the games can also be played in a cooperative manner.

A game that increases knowledge about the Lech PoznaÅ„ team, the rules of football, and encourages physical activity!

The work of a footballer is associated with great responsibility and great prestige. 
Do you know what it is? 
How to behave on the pitch and what is the history of the club you love so much? 
Test your knowledge, fitness and become a Little Lechita!

Contents:
- a board
- a shield with arrows
- 60 cards with questions / tasks
- Little Lechity certificates
- 4 pawns
- instruction
- a dice
This is a cool trick taking game where the players try to get travelling routes for their planes.
This new card game reflects the fascinating world of river shipping. The winner is the first player to collect a complete set of tug-boat and barges, complemented with a skipper.

Tu préfères !?. is a party game in which we must secretly classify 4 incongruous situations, from the "least bad" to the worst. You have to try to be as close as possible to the rankings of other players.

—description from the designer (translated)
So fängt es an an educational game for kids to learn to write: The first letter is given and they need to find the others. The picture on the first letter card might help therefore.

The goal of the game is to make the greatest number of squares of your color on a suggested board of 5x5 or 7x7 squares.
Players have squares representing 4 triangles of 4 colors in one of six possible configurations!
Cube² offers several game modes: with 2 or 4 players, each for himself or in teams of 2 in the 4 player version (2x2), or a more original formula 4 players per team (2x2), the principle of which is: to win the part you must first beat the opposing team (cumulative score), then achieve a number of SQUARE greater than that of your teammate!

—description from the publisher (translated)

There is a huge festival in the zoo today. There is free popcorn and ice cream for visitors and many delicacies for the animals. The children are allowed to stroke some of the young animals, and they can even ride others.

But the best thing about the festival is the guessing game with the talking parrots. Because if the parrot repeats the spoken word, you win the corresponding object.

Who will guess and who will win the most things?

—description from the back of the box (translated)
This is a card game where every kid gets 3 cards and tries to discard cards whoch sum up to 12. The kid who created the most sets of cards with the sum of 12 wins.

The youngest player starts on his way to become a calculating star! He rolls two dice and needs to create a story with the sum of the dice and his cards. If he calculates wrongly, he will not get the card. The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

Great Cities: Washington, DC allows two to four players the ability to explore 150 years of history, culture, political intrigue and urban development in our nation's capital.

The game begins in 1871 and is played over eight 20-year generations (ending in 2030).  Each generation, players receive income and draft development cards.  Then players building housing for increased population, pay and play development and culture cards, and otherwise build out the city.

After eight generations, players score their buildings, cards and secret agenda cards to determine a winner.

—description from the publisher

Tabletop minatures wargames rules.

Scales:
1mm : 1 yard
1 turn : 1 minute

Variable figure scales according to size of figures/vehicles used:
6mm figures : 1 figure = 1 man
15mm figures : 1 figure = 10 man
25mm figures : 1 figure = 25 man

Units of 100 men/50 cavalry/4-6 vehicles or guns

Overall battle scale is approximately brigade (multiple battalions)

A free PnP asymmetrical Monopoly game inspired by the classic Dune board game.

Unlike traditional Monopoly, players can choose between five different factions, each with unique abilities and win conditions. Each player will have four fighters they can use to attack others and lay claim to the enemy's strongholds but it will always be at a cost.

Players should also be careful of the very planet itself, as Arrakis is a harsh place and to survive it will take its toll. Luckily, if a player owns certain territories they either gain by force or are naturally given it from the start, they can receive riches in the form of the spice melange.

With the spice, players can bribe and trade with each other and afford to survive in the hostile deserts of Arrakis. But players should be cautious, as deals can be broken and players can lie their way to getting spice. Calling them out on not following through on a deal or catching them in a lie can cause them to lose a turn but a player falsely accusing someone of lying can have harsher consequences.

The game ends when any of the unique faction specific winning conditions are met.

Rorschach, named after the Swiss psychiatrist Hermann Rorschach, uses some of his famous inkblot images (and many new ones) to put two teams to the test. The teams earn points by correctly guessing how their members paired randomly selected words with these inkblot images.

Reading the other players and learning their associations is the key to success, but the real fascination lies in seeing how differently these images can be perceived — and in discussing and explaining the pairings afterwards.

—description from the publisher

Samurai Sword is a game based on the proven Bang! mechanisms and set in feudal Japan. In this game, the familiar features of Bang! are enhanced by more dynamic and fast-paced game play, and thanks to a new scoring system – based on honor points and resilience points – there is no player elimination. Everybody gets to fight to the very end! Also, weapons and attacks are fused into a single card.

—description from the publisher

This edition contains the Rising Sun expansion.

"Sacrilicious" -- Board Game Quest, Best Board Games of 2021

Illumination is a game of Mad Medieval Monks and Illuminated Manuscripts.

You and your opponent are monks competing to become the new head of the Scriptorium. You do so by illuminating manuscripts with elaborate religious artwork. But not all is as peaceful as it once was! Possessed with eccentric enthusiasm, one of you has turned from the reverent to the irreverent by scrawling demons instead of angels and by painting fierce dragons instead of noble knights. Who will become the new master of the Scriptorium? Will it be the monk who reverently illuminates the page with monks, dogs, knights and angels; or the irreverent monk who whimsically draws the forces of rabbit, squirrel, dragon and demon? Play Illumination to find out!

OBJECT

Each turn, players create illuminations in three Books by placing one full row or column of tiles of their choice from their Player mat. With careful placement, players collect Coins that  allow  them  to perform special actions or  purchase Scriptorium cards. By placing tiles next to others of matching color, players collect Ritual tokens to score points at the Ritual stations in the Monastery when they are occupied by the Abbot.

As tiles are placed in Books, conflicts are set in motion:  Angels wrestle with Demons, Knights skirmish with Dragons,  Monks contend with Rabbits, and Dogs struggle with Squirrels. These conflicts are resolved only when they are bounded on all sides. Then, the player with more tiles on their side wins the 
Bounded Battle, flips the losing side’s tiles facedown, and places their Marker on the matching Battle card.

When the game ends, players score points for the Rituals  recorded on the Monastery mat and 1 point for each of their faceup Illumination tiles in each Book. Players also score points for placing more Markers on Battle cards and for defeated factions that match their Crusade card. The player with more points wins!

-description from publisher

æ›‡å¤©ï¼æ–¬åˆ Tactics (ã©ã‚“ã¦ã‚“ã®ãã‚Šã‚ã„ Tactics) Donten no Kiriai Tactics is a Japanese game for two players. It is a simpler game than the original æ›‡å¤©ï¼æ–¬åˆ Legend (Donten no Kiriai Legend) to let players learn the basic game before progressing to the full edition. The designer includes solitaire rules.

Two Samurais duel, using basic movement and attack cards.

Measure the distance with your opponent and decide on a blow! As a samurai, all you can do is change your stance, advance or retreat, and slash. The duel continues hot and fast, round after round, until one of the Samurai succumbs to their wounds.

The players take a basic deck of six cards. Players set up the duelling positions, with the Samurai initially being two steps apart, and then each secretly chooses a hand card face-down. When they are ready, the cards are turned up.

The basic cards involve the Samurai advancing or retreating, and adopting different stances. If the Samurai move close enough together, and onto the same spot, then a strike can happen.

Basic attacks can be made repeatedly, the card goes back to the player's hand when used.

A round ends when a successful strike is made, and damage is shown on the attacking card. The player struck loses hit points.

The first player to lose all their health loses the duel.
user summary

Both the original The Quacks of Quedlinburg, and The Herb Witches expansion, all packaged up in one big box bundle! Also thrown in for good measure is the mini-expansion, Wolfgang’s Exchange Office.

In The Quacks of Quedlinburg, players are charlatans — or quack doctors — each making their own secret brew by adding ingredients one at a time. Take care with what you add, though, for a pinch too much of this or that will spoil the whole mixture!

Each player has their own bag of ingredient chips. During each round, they simultaneously draw chips and add them to their pot. The higher the face value of the drawn chip, the further it is placed in the swirling pattern, increasing how much your potion is worth. Push your luck as far as you can, but if you add too many cherry bombs, your pot explodes!

At the end of each round, players gain victory points and coins to spend on new ingredients to add to their bags, depending on the strength of the ingredients in their pots. But players with exploded pots must choose points or coins — not both! The player with the most victory points at the end of nine rounds wins the game.

Included in this box are:


     Quacks: the base game
     The Quacks of Quedlinburg: The Herb Witches: the first expansion, adding Witches that grant powers once per game as well as more ingredient books.
     The Quacks of Quedlinburg: Wolfgang's Exchange Office: a mini-expansion adding new conditions for end-game scoring.
A game of War illustrated by Andrzej Mleczko. Rules for Kuku and 3-5-8 are inluded in the box.

The party game known as Dupa biskupa can be played with any set of cards and any number of players, over any number of rounds. There is one general rule; the more players there are, the more cards are required.

The game starts with cards being dealt so that each player receives the same amount. Starting from the first, players lay down cards in such a way that everyone can see the card. Having laid the card, the player has to perform a certain action established before starting the game, and corresponding to the suit and rank of the card. Some suits or ranks require that the player perform no action.

Player who perform the wrong action, or fail to perform one when required, is obliged to take the pile of cards.

The winner of each round attributes a way of acting to other cards in the next round, but the actions for queens, kings and aces remains the same.

The first player to empty their hand wins the game.

One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Quiz of the year 2020'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about quiz of the year 2020. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

—user summary
Roll the three coloured dice, and be the first to find the corresponding cupcake. Whoever gets the most cupcakes wind the game.

A game about knitting, whether you are new to knitting or have experience in knitting. Start your work, do your stitches, swap works with your opponents, change colour. Games with simple stitches, games with advanced stitches.

One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Vacation'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about vacation. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

—user summary

Fast paced game of word categories. Players compete to be the first to correctly call out a corresponding word in the current category.

On each game turn, the games master calls out a word category, all participants are to listen and respond as fast as possible with a correct example of the mentioned category.

Before beginning the game, the players agree on required number of cards for a winner to emerge based on how long they want to play for. The game ends once a player attains the predetermined number of cards.

-description from designer

Unmatched is a highly asymmetrical miniature fighting game for two or four players. Each hero is represented by a unique deck designed to evoke their style and legend. Tactical movement and no-luck combat resolution create a unique play experience that rewards expertise, but just when you've mastered one set, new heroes arrive to provide all new match-ups.

Unmatched: Hell's Kitchen features three characters from the Marvel comics universe: Daredevil, Elektra, and Bullseye.

Unmatched is a highly asymmetrical miniature fighting game for two or four players. Each hero is represented by a unique deck designed to evoke their style and legend. Tactical movement and no-luck combat resolution create a unique play experience that rewards expertise, but just when you've mastered one set, new heroes arrive to provide all new match-ups.

Unmatched: For King and Country features three characters from the Marvel comics universe: Black Widow, Black Panther, and Winter Soldier.

In 2014, Castles of Mad King Ludwig brought out the interior designer in all of us with its unique combination of mechanisms and opportunity to be a visionary architect at work! It became an instant classic for many, wanting to play again and again creating endless, luxurious castles, while also attempting to achieve the most victory points over their opponents. This incredible collector's edition of the tile placement classic would be oh-so-pleasing to King Ludwig II of Bavaria…

Featuring:

     All New Artwork
     An incredible Dual Sided Scoreboard 
     GameTrayz Storage Organizers
     Weighted Swan Player Markers
     New Kings Favors & Bonus Cards
     Existing Expansions
     The New Royal Decrees Expansion
     The New Towers Expansion: Including 8 detailed 3D Miniatures
     5th Player Option & More!


—description from the publisher

This bite-size edition of the well-known game TRIVIAL PURSUIT is exclusively dedicated to Sporting Clube de Portugal.

This is the travel edition of the Sporting Clube de Portugal Trivial Pursuit with about 600 questions about the history of this Centenary Club.

Test your knowledge of the Club and its history!

Fronteiras de Sangue / Borders of Blood is a system of wargame rules focused on the greatest war in the history of South America, the War of Paraguay, or War of the Triple Alliance, or, still, Guasú War (Great War).

The confrontation was fought between Paraguay and the Triple Alliance, composed of Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay, and extended from December 1864 to March 1870.

Features:

     Battalion level rules for 6 to 28mm minis
     Action dice to randomize number of actions that troops can take each turn
     Action card to randomize events each turn
     original combat system
     army list (including generals) for the 4 belligerents
     2 scenarios

Monopoly: Mega Édition Beauvais is bigger and believe it or not, faster than regular Monopoly. 
What makes it bigger is a larger board, Train Depots, Skyscrapers, 9 new Properties. 
It is faster because of a new speed die and Bus cards. 
Monopoly: Mega Édition Beauvais can be played in 1½ hours with more fun than ever!

The massive game board has 12 additional spaces.

Buy all the properties of a group, build your houses and hotels, and then keep on going by building Skyscrapers for a chance to earn mega rents. 
Good news: you can build houses and hotels once you own three out of four properties in a group (or two out of three in the smaller groups). You can even build a Depot on a railroad to double its rent.

Roll three dice on your turn: two regular dice and the special "Speed" Die. The Speed Die gives you a chance for free trip to the next available property. (Later in the game the Speed Die could send you to the next property you owe rent on. Ouch!) From time to time you'll earn free "Bus Tickets." Use them to go where you want to go, but beware: they expire! The Speed Die and the Bus Tickets make the action speedy, intense, and sure-fire fun!

Forces of Nature is a simple yet sophisticated card game where 2-4 players must fight to win as the last player standing. Each turn, players draw cards and make tough decisions. Players use the available Will – a growing economy for the round – to bring cards from their hand into the Wild – the gameplay area. Once in the Wild, players command their cards and animals to battle opponents.

Animal, Force, and Nature cards with their own unique abilities may seem simple by themselves, but masterfully combining them can lead to some exceptionally thrilling matches.


     Animals – like the Gorilla – can attack other animals and players in the Wild, and can also be used to defend attacks from opponents.
     Force cards – such as Patience – can make opponents reevaluate their strategy by making permanent changes to animals during the game.
     Nature cards – including Volcano – change the course of the game by directly impacting players and animals in the Wild.


Force of Nature is a special card that can deal a devastating blow to opponents – it removes all animals for all players in the Wild. Used at just the right moment, this card can dramatically turn the tables on unsuspecting players.

The last surviving player wins Forces of Nature.

—description from the designer

Each player will interpret the role of a planetary architect who will try to create a new home for mankind, which by its mistakes, condemned the ancient Earth ...

Simply you have to choose an action among the three possible (play a card to take all those of the same ecosystem, pick up the cards according to the numbers on the card played, or play it in your game zone). With this idea, NUEVOS MUNDOS is a challenge with a depth and elegance mechanics but with a very easy  concept.

When the universe board cannot be filled with cards, each world created by each player will be scored with a scoring system that simulates the harmony between ecosystems, animals and plants and conditions for life in the world. But be careful, the elements that don´t meet this balance will be penalized.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Cada jugador representa el papel de un arquitecto planetario que tratará de crear un nuevo hogar para una humanidad, que por sus errores, condenó la antigua Tierra...

Con solo elegir una acción entre las tres disponibles (jugar una carta para coger todas las del mismo ecosistema, para coger las que comparten dígito o jugarla en tu zona de juego) NUEVOS MUNDOS supone un desafío con una profundidad y elegancia que no suele verse en juegos a priori tan sencillos.

Cuando el tablero del universo no se pueda rellenar de cartas, se puntuará cada mundo creado por cada jugador con un sistema de puntuación que simula la armonía entre ecosistemas, fauna y flora y, sobre todo, condiciones para la vida en él. Pero cuidado, que los elementos que no cumplan este equilibrio penalizarán.

—description from the publisher

The Miko sex memory game is played just like the popular memory game. All cards are shuffled face down on the table. As many pairs as possible should be found. But beware! There are also 24 crazy tasks in this game. The tasks are divided into two halves, which in turn are on different cards. If you happened to turn the left and right halves of an order while playing this memory game, then you will have to complete this order on the spot, to the glee of all players.

—user summary

A complete kit to organize an incredible escape game evening with friends, in one of the most oppressive worlds: the Chernobyl power station, in Ukraine, transformed into a death trap. 
An unprecedented catastrophe will shake your life when, following hazardous handling, Reactor No. 4 melts.

Try to escape, find iodine pills, the right combination, a vehicle and… get out of the disaster scene as soon as possible!

—description from the publisher

Ecologies: Bizarre Biomes is the second game in the series. It is playable as a stand alone game or used in combination with the original Ecologies card game. Designed by a biology teacher, the game includes 77 unique organisms, 7 biomes, and beautiful vintage Victorian art. (108 cards total). Gameplay is rooted in authentic science, as it is used in the classroom to teach real concepts to biology students. While it is scientific enough for the classroom, it is also strategic enough for any game night.

This game is a sequel AND an expansion. When using the game as an expansion, you can customize the deck to include cards from both games, including cards you love and excluding ones you don’t. Some players love aggressive “take that” mechanics, while others find them stressful. Some players love particular healthy ecology bonuses, while others feel they are overpowered. With multiple decks, you can create a customized experience to fit your group. If you’d like to maintain the same game length and feel, we recommend choosing 10 factor cards and 7 different biomes.

Players build and maintain food webs in diverse environments. Healthy ecologies reward you with bonus powers and perks. Watch out though, as others may decide it’s easier to disturb and degrade your ecosystem than nurture their own.

Cards are arranged with plants on the bottom and predators on top. Players negotiate trades and use biotic and abiotic factor cards to affect their webs and the webs of players around them. It is a race to get to 12 victory points, with players using different strategies such as focusing on one biome, going for perks and bonuses, or disrupting other ecologies.

The points system is based on ecological trophic levels. The producers (plants) are worth less and as you make your way up the pyramid organisms are worth more, as it takes a lot of energy to sustain them. In real life only roughly 10% of the energy makes it from one level to the next, meaning you have to have acres of land and hundreds of animals just to sustain one apex predator.

—description from the designer

Lockpick is a solo game in which the player attempts to work with randomly-drawn cards to create Rummy-style sets of three in various columns. The theme is one of breaking in to a security system via lockpicking and computer hacking. Designed for the Looney Pyramids family, Lockpick requires a Zark City deck (or other five-suited deck from with values from 1-13), 15 pyramids in five colors, and two dice: a standard D6 and a specialized color die.

In more detail, the card deck is separated into five piles by color with space left below each pile to form a column. Space for a discard pile goes off to the side. Each turn, the player begins with an empty hand and rolls the two dice. The numeral on the D6 determines how many cards the player must draw, and the color die determines what color pile the player must draw from. With these cards in hand, the player must now distribute them among the columns beneath the color piles, using a mancala-style distribution that wraps around and will cause newer cards to cascade down, partially covering previously-placed cards. Any three-card sets that are created within the columns are now removed along with the colored pyramid that sits above that column.

Once a color pile is depeleted, subsequent die rolls of that color allow the player to remove a matching color card from one of the columns and reposition it at the bottom of any column desired, thus allowing for the possibility of sets being created through the joining of two previously unconnected groups of cards within a single column, along with the rare opportunity for two sets to be formed at once. Victory is achieved when a player has successfully defeated all 15 security measures (represented by the 15 pyramids). Defeat occurs when all the cards have been depleted while there are pyramids still standing.

The survey ship U.S.S. Sus has just a few more tweaks, checks, and tests to undergo before it can begin its mission in deep space.  However, not everyone wants to see the ship succeed at exploring far planets.  Intruders have boarded the ship and are disguised as part of the astronaut crew.  Can the astronauts find the intruders  and expel them from the ship before it is too late?

U.S.S. Sus is a hidden role game where 5-11 players take on the roles of the astronauts or intruders and then try to figure out who they can trust and who is suspicious.

The game is played in rounds and each round has three phases.  In the first phase all players secretly choose a location in the ship to work in.  In the second phase players will find out who else is working in the same room, and then the intruder players can attempt to kill a player in the same or adjacent room.  In the final phase the players discuss who is an intruder and decide if someone is going out an airlock.

—description from the designer

Players lead groups of kids in building micronations that will fight for economic and territorial supremacy of the neighborhood. The game takes place on a map made of hexagons. During the game players can have their kids build forts or work at headquarters to grow their economy and gain resources. Supply lines must be maintained to transfer this wealth. Each micronation can also print their own currency which they can use for trade or negotiations with other micronations. The value of this currency can be brought up or down for manipulative purposes. Other optional strategies involve combat or social infiltration to convert kids from other micronations. Aside from these challenges kids must avoid parents who randomly wander the map in attempts to make them go home. The player with the most stored resources at the end of the game is the winner.

—description from the designer

NOTE: The first edition of Micronations was named Neighborhood Conflict. It was known under that name in years 2011–2013.

     Not to be confused with first edition of Tactical Friction, which was also named Neighborhood Conflict, but got renamed to Tactical Friction in 2008.
     Not to be confused with Neighborhood Conflict.
The players start at space 1. The first to reach space 19 wins the game. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

Extra deck of cards for Cards Against IT with Security based cards.
Pomotion item from Varonis, an IT security company

The players start at the starting space. The first to reach the space with the treasure trunk wins the game. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players. If a player gets on an occupied space, the other player has to go back to the next car of his color. On the blue spaces the players may change direction.

Unlock! is a co-operative card game inspired by escape rooms that uses a simple system which allows you to search scenes, combine objects, and solve riddles. Play Unlock! to embark on great adventures, while seated at a table using only cards.

Unlock!: Kids is designed for players ages 6+ and unlike other Unlock! titles, it does not require an app.

• Mac Unlock's Castle - Scotland is yours, and so are its ghosts. . . and treasures!

• Feather Balls & Mysteries - Lead the investigation among the animals and restore peace to the barnyard!

• Fuss at the Park - Meet the wacky inhabitants of this fantastic amusement park.

Contents:
1 Rulebook
1 Tutorial (11 Cards)
3 Stories (150 Cards)
7 Starting Special Components
38 Cardboard Tokens
1 Hints & Solutions Booklet

In Theorem, players will be dealt 7 cards and attempt to get rid of their cards by playing them in sets. Players will follow their own rule cards, but can also use rules revealed by other players. When a player plays 7 cards, then they win!

—description from the publisher

De Bellis Renationis is a set of wargames rules for Renaissance battles covering the period from 1494 AD to 1700 AD.
 DBR version 2.0 offers a combination of realism and excitement for this warfare using miniature figures in any scale from 30mm to 2mm. 
The creation of experienced wargame designers Phil Barker and Richard Bodley Scott, DBR can be used to refight historical engagements or your own scenarios from small scale skirmishes to the largest battles of the period. 
With its command system using "player initiative points", DBR emphasizes the player's generalship rather than his ability to manipulate a set of rules. It allows players to fight actions from the whole period and across the whole world, from Japan to Europe and the Americas and from the Italian Wars to the Nine Years War.

This edition combines the 2002 edition of the rules with all three of the books of Army Lists and includes everything the wargamer needs to refight these battles in one single convenient volume.

—description from the back of the book

Your big day has arrived! As a young engineer at the famous Freeze Factory, you have spent years developing a pioneering ice cream machine. 
It can scoop 3 different flavours at one into a cone. Today is your chance to present your invention to the world and treat your guests to delicious ice cream. But who is the best at operating the machine, getting the combination of flavours right and serving the most people?

Aim of the game:
The aim is to serve as many people as possible, collecting the most cones, by skilfully moving the flavour tiles.

Gameplay:
You decide whether or not to roll the dice. 
If you roll, the number you roll is your number of movement points. If you do not roll, you get exactly 3 movement points.

If you manage, either during or at the end of your turn, to create a row of three ice cream flavours on the board that matches the flavours in one of the cones in your hand, you have served the cone and can place it face-up in front of you. Remember that the flavours must be in a horizontal or vertical row; diagonal lines or rows that go over the edge of the board do not count. 
If you have no more cones in your hand, you take a new cone from the draw pile.

Game End:
The game ends when a player who has just served a cone is unable to take a new card because the draw pile has been used up. The player who has collected the most cones wins.
